usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unscheduled or infrequent application backups leading to potential data loss
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of data loss and downtime due to operational failure or security breaches is a concern with stateful applications, even if backup and recovery mechanisms are in place.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious actors seeking to disrupt or compromise the application and its data. Attack vectors may include unauthorized access to the application and its storage, injection of malicious code, or intentional deletion or corruption of data.
Impacts
The impacts of a successful attack or operational failure could include loss of data, extended downtime, potential regulatory non-compliance, and damage to the organization's reputation and trust.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to the application and its backup data, leading to the theft or deletion of critical information. 2. Malicious code injection results in the corruption or encryption of application data, rendering backups unusable for recovery. 3. Operational failure, such as misconfiguration or human error, causes accidental deletion or overwriting of critical data, leading to service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Outdated or misconfigured anti-malware exposing Linux endpoints to advanced threats
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of outdated or improperly configured anti-malware solutions on Linux environments can result in increased vulnerability to malware and other cyber threats. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may exploit vulnerabilities in outdated anti-malware solutions, or bypass improperly configured solutions to deliver and execute malware on Linux systems. 
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include potential compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized access to systems, disruption of services, and exploitation of vulnerabilities for further attacks. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a known vulnerability in an outdated anti-malware solution on a Linux server, gaining unauthorized access to sensitive data and compromising the integrity of the system. Alternatively, an attacker bypasses a misconfigured anti-malware solution to deliver and execute malware on a Linux endpoint, leading to further compromise and disruption of services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Unauthorized access to VMs due to improper RBAC management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to VM by former employees or unauthorized personnel can lead to data breaches, service disruption, or unauthorized data modification. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Former employees with revoked access, malicious insiders, or external attackers may attempt to gain access using compromised credentials, social engineering, or other unauthorized means. 
Impacts
Unauthorized access to the VM can lead to unauthorized data access, data exfiltration, service disruption, and potential modification of critical resources. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An ex-employee whose access was not properly revoked may still have access to the VM and can potentially exfiltrate sensitive data or disrupt services. A malicious insider could abuse their administrative privileges to access, modify, or delete critical data. External attackers might conduct credential stuffing attacks to gain unauthorized access to the VM.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to unencrypted customer data
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access to data at rest and in transit arises when encryption using customer-managed keys is not implemented, exposing sensitive information to potential compromise. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could exploit weak or absent encryption controls, intercept data in transit through unsecured channels, gain unauthorized access to data at rest, or compromise encryption keys through unauthorized means. 
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized access to sensitive data, potential data breaches, compromise of confidentiality and integrity, regulatory non-compliance, and reputational damage to the organization. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker intercepts unencrypted data transmitted over unsecured channels, such as HTTP, and extracts sensitive information from the communication. 2. A threat actor gains unauthorized access to unencrypted data at rest on virtual disks within Azure, potentially resulting in the exposure of sensitive information. 3. A malicious insider obtains unauthorized access to encryption keys, leading to the decryption of protected data and the compromise of confidentiality and integrity. 4. Attackers exploit legacy encryption protocols, such as SSL 3.0 or TLS v1.0, to exploit known vulnerabilities and gain access to sensitive data during transmission.

threat.name: Unauthorized installation of Azure Monitor agent on virtual machines
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access to sensitive data and systems in Azure virtual machines due to insufficient monitoring and protection measures. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could exploit vulnerabilities in the virtual machines' operating systems or applications to gain unauthorized access. Attack vectors may include network-based attacks, malware injection, and exploitation of misconfigurations. 
Impacts
The impacts could range from unauthorized data access and exfiltration to disruption of services, data manipulation, and potential installation of backdoors for future attacks. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a vulnerability in an unmonitored virtual machine, gaining access to sensitive data and deploying malware to evade detection by Defender for Servers and Azure Monitor. The attacker exfiltrates data or disrupts services without being noticed.

threat.name: Inadequate Network Security Group configuration for Azure VM Subnets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to network resources within the Azure environment can lead to a variety of security issues, including data breaches, service disruption, and unauthorized system manipulation. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can attempt to gain unauthorized access to network resources by exploiting misconfigured network security controls, performing port scanning to identify open ports, or attempting to bypass network filtering mechanisms. 
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized access to network resources can include data exfiltration, service disruption, unauthorized system manipulation, and potential compromise of sensitive information. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a misconfigured Network Security Group (NSG) on a subnet within an Azure environment. The attacker exploits this misconfiguration to gain unauthorized access to open ports, allowing them to exfiltrate sensitive data or disrupt services within the network.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Unauthorized access via embedded credentials and misconfigured Azure AD
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access and compromise of sensitive data arises when default authentication methods are not securely implemented, secrets and credentials are embedded in code or configuration files, and proper conditions and criteria for access control are not defined. Additionally, the use of service principals instead of managed identities can lead to unauthorized access and misuse of privileges. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit weak authentication methods, credentials embedded in code or configuration files, and lack of proper access controls. Attack vectors may include credential theft, unauthorized access from untrusted locations, and exploitation of service principal vulnerabilities. 
Impacts
The impacts of these threats include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, unauthorized modification or deletion of data, and potential compromise of the entire workload and infrastructure. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains access to code or configuration files containing embedded credentials, allowing them to impersonate legitimate users and access sensitive data. 

2. Malicious actors exploit weak authentication methods to gain unauthorized access to Azure resources and perform unauthorized actions within the workload. 

3. Attackers bypass conditional access policies and gain entry from untrusted or risky locations, potentially compromising data and resources. 

4. Threat actors exploit vulnerabilities in service principals to gain unauthorized access to Azure services and compromise the security of managed resources.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized application execution on VMs via Microsoft Defender and Azure Policy
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized applications running on virtual machines (VMs) can pose a threat to the security and stability of the environment. Without proper controls in place, malicious or unapproved applications could be executed, leading to potential exploitation of vulnerabilities or unauthorized access to sensitive data. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unintentional user actions. Attack vectors could involve exploiting vulnerabilities in applications, executing unauthorized scripts, or running unapproved software on the VMs. 
Impacts
The impact of unauthorized applications running on VMs can range from unauthorized access to sensitive information, introducing malware or viruses into the environment, disrupting the availability of services, or circumventing security controls. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a VM and installs a backdoor application that allows for persistent access and reconnaissance within the organization's network. Alternatively, an employee accidentally installs an unauthorized application that contains malware, leading to the compromise of the VM and potential spread to other resources in the environment.

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to unpatched vulnerabilities and misconfigured Azure VMs
threat.desc:
General threat description
Implementing a control to maintain the security configuration of the operating system and ensuring the installation of security updates on Azure virtual machines is crucial to protect against threats targeting misconfigurations and known vulnerabilities in the cloud environment. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious actors, automated bots, or insiders seeking to exploit misconfigurations, unpatched vulnerabilities, and insecure baseline configurations on Azure virtual machines. Attack vectors may involve direct exploitation through known vulnerabilities or indirect attacks leveraging weak security configurations. 
Impacts
The impacts of inadequate security configuration maintenance and patch management include unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exploitation of known security vulnerabilities to compromise the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of Azure virtual machines and associated resources. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a known vulnerability in an unpatched Linux VM, gaining unauthorized access and exfiltrating sensitive data. Another scenario involves an insider making unauthorized changes to the security configuration of an Azure compute resource, leading to a security breach and potential exposure of critical assets to malicious actors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-1104
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1104: Use of Unmaintained Third Party Components The product relies on third-party components that are not actively supported or maintained by the original developer or a trusted proxy for the original developer.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-321
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-321: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key The use of a hard-coded cryptographic key significantly increases the possibility that encrypted data may be recovered.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Enable threat detection capabilities
countermeasure.desc: Use the threat detection capability of Microsoft Defender for Cloud for the respective Azure services. For threat detection not included in Microsoft Defender services, refer to Microsoft Cloud Security Benchmark service baselines for the respective services to enable the threat detection or security alert capabilities within the service. Ingest alerts and log data from Microsoft Defender for Cloud, Microsoft 365 Defender, and log data from other resources into your Azure Monitor or Microsoft Sentinel instances to build analytics rules, which hunt detect threats and create alerts that match specific criteria across your environment. For Operational Technology (OT) environments that include computers that control or monitor Industrial Control System (ICS) or Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) resources, use Microsoft Defender for IoT to inventory assets and detect threats and vulnerabilities. For services that do not have a native threat detection capability, consider collecting the data plane logs and analyze the threats through Microsoft Sentinel.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in transit
countermeasure.desc: Enforce secure transfer in services such as Azure Storage, where a native data in transit encryption feature is built in. Enforce HTTPS for web application workloads and services by ensuring that any clients connecting to your Azure resources use transport layer security (TLS) v1.2 or later. For remote management of VMs, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol. For remote management of Azure virtual machines, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol. For secure file transfer, use the SFTP/FTPS service in Azure Storage Blob, App Service apps, and Function apps, instead of using the regular FTP service. Note: Data in transit encryption is enabled for all Azure traffic traveling between Azure datacenters. TLS v1.2 or later is enabled on most Azure services by default. And some services such as Azure Storage and Application Gateway can enforce TLS v1.2 or later on the server side.

countermeasure.name: Ensure regular automated backups
countermeasure.desc: For Azure Backup supported resources (such as Azure VMs, SQL Server, HANA databases, Azure PostgreSQL Database, File Shares, Blobs or Disks), enable Azure Backup and configure the desired frequency and retention period. For Azure VM, you can use Azure Policy to have backup automatically enabled using Azure Policy. For resources or services not supported by Azure Backup, use the native backup capability provided by the resource or service. For example, Azure Key Vault provides a native backup capability. For resources/services that are neither supported by Azure Backup nor have a native backup capability, evaluate your backup and disaster needs, and create your own mechanism as per your business requirements. For example: - If you use Azure Storage for data storage, enable blob versioning for your storage blobs which will allow you to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your Azure Storage. - Service configuration settings can usually be exported to Azure Resource Manager templates.

countermeasure.name: Establish network segmentation boundaries
countermeasure.desc:
Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.
Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address. Refer to NS-7 Simplify network security configuration to use Adaptive Network Hardening to recommend NSG hardening rules based on threat intelligence and traffic analysis result.
You can also use application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration. Instead of defining policy based on explicit IP addresses in network security groups, ASGs enable you to configure network security as a natural extension of an application's structure, allowing you to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups.

countermeasure.name: Follow just enough administration (least privilege) principle
countermeasure.desc: Use Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC) to manage Azure resource access through role assignments. Through RBAC, you can assign roles to users, groups, service principals, and managed identities. There are pre-defined built-in roles for certain resources, and these roles can be inventoried or queried through tools such as Azure CLI, Azure PowerShell, and the Azure portal. The privileges you assign to resources through Azure RBAC should always be limited to what's required by the roles. Limited privileges will complement the just-in-time (JIT) approach of Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM), and those privileges should be reviewed periodically. If required, you can also use PIM to define a time-bound assignment, which is a condition in a role assignment where a user can only activate the role within the specified start and end dates. Note: Use Azure built-in roles to allocate permissions and only create custom roles when required.

countermeasure.name: Manage application identities securely and automatically
countermeasure.desc: Use Azure managed identities, which can authenticate to Azure services and resources that support Azure AD authentication. Managed identity credentials are fully managed, rotated, and protected by the platform, avoiding hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files. For services that don't support managed identities, use Azure AD to create a service principal with restricted permissions at the resource level. It is recommended to configure service principals with certificate credentials and fall back to client secrets for authentication.

countermeasure.name: Perform vulnerability assessments
countermeasure.desc: Follow recommendations from Microsoft Defender for Cloud for performing vulnerability assessments on your Azure virtual machines, container images, and SQL servers. Microsoft Defender for Cloud has a built-in vulnerability scanner for virtual machines. Use a third-party solution for performing vulnerability assessments on network devices and applications (e.g., web applications) Export scan results at consistent intervals and compare the results with previous scans to verify that vulnerabilities have been remediated. When using vulnerability management recommendations suggested by Microsoft Defender for Cloud, you can pivot into the selected scan solution's portal to view historical scan data. When conducting remote scans, do not use a single, perpetual, administrative account. Consider implementing JIT (Just In Time) provisioning methodology for the scan account. Credentials for the scan account should be protected, monitored, and used only for vulnerability scanning. Note: Microsoft Defender services (including Defender for servers, containers, App Service, Database, and DNS) embed certain vulnerability assessment capabilities. The alerts generated from Azure Defender services should be monitored and reviewed together with the result from Microsoft Defender for Cloud vulnerability scanning tool. Note: Ensure you setup email notifications in Microsoft Defender for Cloud.

countermeasure.name: Restrict resource access based on conditions
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure AD conditional access for more granular access controls based on user-defined conditions, such as requiring user logins from certain IP ranges (or devices) to use MFA. Azure AD Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organizations apps based on certain conditions.
Define the applicable conditions and criteria for Azure AD conditional access in the workload. Consider the following common use cases: - Requiring multi-factor authentication for users with administrative roles - Requiring multi-factor authentication for Azure management tasks - Blocking sign-ins for users attempting to use legacy authentication protocols - Requiring trusted locations for Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication registration - Blocking or granting access from specific locations - Blocking risky sign-in behaviors - Requiring organization-managed devices for specific applications
Note: Granular authentication session management controls can also be implemented through Azure AD conditional access policies such as sign-in frequency and persistent browser session.

countermeasure.name: Restrict the exposure of credential and secrets
countermeasure.desc: When using a managed identity is not an option, ensure that secrets and credentials are stored in secure locations such as Azure Key Vault, instead of embedding them into the code and configuration files. If you use Azure DevOps and GitHub for your code management platform: - Implement Azure DevOps Credential Scanner to identify credentials within the code. - For GitHub, use the native secret scanning feature to identify credentials or other forms of secrets within the code. Clients such as Azure Functions, Azure Apps services, and VMs can use managed identities to access Azure Key Vault securely. See Data Protection controls related to the use of Azure Key Vault for secrets management. Note: Azure Key Vault provides automatic rotation for supported services. For secrets which cannot be automatically rotated, ensure they are manually rotated periodically and purged when no longer in use.

countermeasure.name: Secure cloud native services with network controls
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy private endpoints for all Azure resources that support the Private Link feature, to establish a private access point for the resources. Using Private Link will keep the private connection from routing through the public network.
Note: Certain Azure services may also allow private communication through the service endpoint feature, though it is recommended to use Azure Private Link for secure and private access to services hosted on Azure platform.
For certain services, you can choose to deploy VNet integration for the service where you can restrict/isolate the VNET to establish a private access point for the service.
You also have the option to configure the service native network ACL rules or simply disable public network access to block access from the public network.
For Azure VMs, unless there is a strong use case, you should avoid assigning public IPs/subnet directly to the VM interface and instead use gateway or load balancer services as the front-end for access by the public network.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure key management process
countermeasure.desc: Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys. When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application. To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer. Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

countermeasure.name: Use centralized identity and authentication system
countermeasure.desc: Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's identity and authentication management service. You should standardize on Azure AD to govern your organization's identity and authentication in: - Microsoft cloud resources, such as Azure Storage, Azure Virtual Machines (Linux and Windows), Azure Key Vault, PaaS, and SaaS applications. - Your organization's resources, such as applications on Azure, third-party applications running on your corporate network resources, and third-party SaaS applications. - Your enterprise identities in Active Directory by synchronization to Azure AD to ensure a consistent and centrally managed identity strategy. For the Azure services that apply, avoid use of local authentication methods and instead use Azure Active Directory to centralize your service authentications. Note: As soon as it is technically feasible, you should migrate on-premises Active Directory-based applications to Azure AD. This could be an Azure AD Enterprise Directory, Business to Business configuration, or Business to consumer configuration.

countermeasure.name: Use customer-managed key option in data at rest encryption when required
countermeasure.desc:
Azure also provides an encryption option using keys managed by yourself (customer-managed keys) for most services.
Azure Key Vault Standard, Premium, and Managed HSM are natively integrated with many Azure Services for customer-managed key use cases. You may use Azure Key Vault to generate your key or bring your own keys.
However, using the customer-managed key option requires additional operational effort to manage the key lifecycle. This may include encryption key generation, rotation, revoke, and access control, etc.

countermeasure.name: Use modern anti-malware software
countermeasure.desc:
Microsoft Defender for Cloud can automatically identify the use of a number of popular anti-malware solutions for your virtual machines and on-premises machines with Azure Arc configured and report the endpoint protection running status and make recommendations.
Microsoft Defender Antivirus is the default anti-malware solution for Windows server 2016 and above. For Windows server 2012 R2, use Microsoft Antimalware extension to enable SCEP (System Center Endpoint Protection). For Linux VMs, use Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on Linux for the endpoint protection feature.
For both Windows and Linux, you can use Microsoft Defender for Cloud to discover and assess the health status of the anti-malware solution.
Note: You can also use Microsoft Defender for Cloud's Defender for Storage to detect malware uploaded to Azure Storage accounts.

countermeasure.name: Use only approved applications in virtual machine
countermeasure.desc: Use Microsoft Defender for Cloud adaptive application controls to discover and generate an application allow list. You can also use ASC adaptive application controls to ensure that only authorized software can executes, and all unauthorized software is blocked from executing on Azure Virtual Machines. Use Azure Automation Change Tracking and Inventory to automate the collection of inventory information from your Windows and Linux VMs. Software name, version, publisher, and refresh time information are available from the Azure portal. To get the software installation date and other information, enable guest-level diagnostics and direct the Windows Event Logs to a Log Analytics workspace. Depending on the type of scripts, you can use operating system-specific configurations or third-party resources to limit users' ability to execute scripts in Azure compute resources. You can also use a third-party solution to discover and identify unapproved software.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unscheduled or infrequent application backups leading to potential data loss
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of data loss and downtime due to operational failure or security breaches is a concern with stateful applications, even if backup and recovery mechanisms are in place.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious actors seeking to disrupt or compromise the application and its data. Attack vectors may include unauthorized access to the application and its storage, injection of malicious code, or intentional deletion or corruption of data.
Impacts
The impacts of a successful attack or operational failure could include loss of data, extended downtime, potential regulatory non-compliance, and damage to the organization's reputation and trust.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to the application and its backup data, leading to the theft or deletion of critical information. 2. Malicious code injection results in the corruption or encryption of application data, rendering backups unusable for recovery. 3. Operational failure, such as misconfiguration or human error, causes accidental deletion or overwriting of critical data, leading to service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Outdated or misconfigured anti-malware exposing Linux endpoints to advanced threats
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of outdated or improperly configured anti-malware solutions on Linux environments can result in increased vulnerability to malware and other cyber threats. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may exploit vulnerabilities in outdated anti-malware solutions, or bypass improperly configured solutions to deliver and execute malware on Linux systems. 
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include potential compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized access to systems, disruption of services, and exploitation of vulnerabilities for further attacks. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a known vulnerability in an outdated anti-malware solution on a Linux server, gaining unauthorized access to sensitive data and compromising the integrity of the system. Alternatively, an attacker bypasses a misconfigured anti-malware solution to deliver and execute malware on a Linux endpoint, leading to further compromise and disruption of services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Unauthorized access to VMs due to improper RBAC management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to VM by former employees or unauthorized personnel can lead to data breaches, service disruption, or unauthorized data modification. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Former employees with revoked access, malicious insiders, or external attackers may attempt to gain access using compromised credentials, social engineering, or other unauthorized means. 
Impacts
Unauthorized access to the VM can lead to unauthorized data access, data exfiltration, service disruption, and potential modification of critical resources. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An ex-employee whose access was not properly revoked may still have access to the VM and can potentially exfiltrate sensitive data or disrupt services. A malicious insider could abuse their administrative privileges to access, modify, or delete critical data. External attackers might conduct credential stuffing attacks to gain unauthorized access to the VM.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to unencrypted customer data
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access to data at rest and in transit arises when encryption using customer-managed keys is not implemented, exposing sensitive information to potential compromise. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could exploit weak or absent encryption controls, intercept data in transit through unsecured channels, gain unauthorized access to data at rest, or compromise encryption keys through unauthorized means. 
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized access to sensitive data, potential data breaches, compromise of confidentiality and integrity, regulatory non-compliance, and reputational damage to the organization. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker intercepts unencrypted data transmitted over unsecured channels, such as HTTP, and extracts sensitive information from the communication. 2. A threat actor gains unauthorized access to unencrypted data at rest on virtual disks within Azure, potentially resulting in the exposure of sensitive information. 3. A malicious insider obtains unauthorized access to encryption keys, leading to the decryption of protected data and the compromise of confidentiality and integrity. 4. Attackers exploit legacy encryption protocols, such as SSL 3.0 or TLS v1.0, to exploit known vulnerabilities and gain access to sensitive data during transmission.

threat.name: Unauthorized installation of Azure Monitor agent on virtual machines
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access to sensitive data and systems in Azure virtual machines due to insufficient monitoring and protection measures. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could exploit vulnerabilities in the virtual machines' operating systems or applications to gain unauthorized access. Attack vectors may include network-based attacks, malware injection, and exploitation of misconfigurations. 
Impacts
The impacts could range from unauthorized data access and exfiltration to disruption of services, data manipulation, and potential installation of backdoors for future attacks. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a vulnerability in an unmonitored virtual machine, gaining access to sensitive data and deploying malware to evade detection by Defender for Servers and Azure Monitor. The attacker exfiltrates data or disrupts services without being noticed.

threat.name: Inadequate Network Security Group configuration for Azure VM Subnets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to network resources within the Azure environment can lead to a variety of security issues, including data breaches, service disruption, and unauthorized system manipulation. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can attempt to gain unauthorized access to network resources by exploiting misconfigured network security controls, performing port scanning to identify open ports, or attempting to bypass network filtering mechanisms. 
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized access to network resources can include data exfiltration, service disruption, unauthorized system manipulation, and potential compromise of sensitive information. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a misconfigured Network Security Group (NSG) on a subnet within an Azure environment. The attacker exploits this misconfiguration to gain unauthorized access to open ports, allowing them to exfiltrate sensitive data or disrupt services within the network.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Unauthorized access via embedded credentials and misconfigured Azure AD
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access and compromise of sensitive data arises when default authentication methods are not securely implemented, secrets and credentials are embedded in code or configuration files, and proper conditions and criteria for access control are not defined. Additionally, the use of service principals instead of managed identities can lead to unauthorized access and misuse of privileges. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit weak authentication methods, credentials embedded in code or configuration files, and lack of proper access controls. Attack vectors may include credential theft, unauthorized access from untrusted locations, and exploitation of service principal vulnerabilities. 
Impacts
The impacts of these threats include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, unauthorized modification or deletion of data, and potential compromise of the entire workload and infrastructure. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains access to code or configuration files containing embedded credentials, allowing them to impersonate legitimate users and access sensitive data. 

2. Malicious actors exploit weak authentication methods to gain unauthorized access to Azure resources and perform unauthorized actions within the workload. 

3. Attackers bypass conditional access policies and gain entry from untrusted or risky locations, potentially compromising data and resources. 

4. Threat actors exploit vulnerabilities in service principals to gain unauthorized access to Azure services and compromise the security of managed resources.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized application execution on VMs via Microsoft Defender and Azure Policy
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized applications running on virtual machines (VMs) can pose a threat to the security and stability of the environment. Without proper controls in place, malicious or unapproved applications could be executed, leading to potential exploitation of vulnerabilities or unauthorized access to sensitive data. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unintentional user actions. Attack vectors could involve exploiting vulnerabilities in applications, executing unauthorized scripts, or running unapproved software on the VMs. 
Impacts
The impact of unauthorized applications running on VMs can range from unauthorized access to sensitive information, introducing malware or viruses into the environment, disrupting the availability of services, or circumventing security controls. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a VM and installs a backdoor application that allows for persistent access and reconnaissance within the organization's network. Alternatively, an employee accidentally installs an unauthorized application that contains malware, leading to the compromise of the VM and potential spread to other resources in the environment.

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to unpatched vulnerabilities and misconfigured Azure VMs
threat.desc:
General threat description
Implementing a control to maintain the security configuration of the operating system and ensuring the installation of security updates on Azure virtual machines is crucial to protect against threats targeting misconfigurations and known vulnerabilities in the cloud environment. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious actors, automated bots, or insiders seeking to exploit misconfigurations, unpatched vulnerabilities, and insecure baseline configurations on Azure virtual machines. Attack vectors may involve direct exploitation through known vulnerabilities or indirect attacks leveraging weak security configurations. 
Impacts
The impacts of inadequate security configuration maintenance and patch management include unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exploitation of known security vulnerabilities to compromise the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of Azure virtual machines and associated resources. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a known vulnerability in an unpatched Linux VM, gaining unauthorized access and exfiltrating sensitive data. Another scenario involves an insider making unauthorized changes to the security configuration of an Azure compute resource, leading to a security breach and potential exposure of critical assets to malicious actors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-89
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS encryption for all connections
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that every client-to-database and inter-node communication is encrypted using robust TLS protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2/1.3), thereby mitigating risks such as eavesdropping and man-in-the-middle attacks. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate TLS configuration into the deployment process and enforce these settings via centralized management tools, ensuring that all data exchanged across the network remains confidential and tamper-proof.

Implementation Steps:

Enable TLS Encryption:

  • Configure the Other Data Store to require TLS for all incoming and outgoing connections by setting the appropriate parameters in the configuration files.

Configure Secure Cipher Suites:

  • Enforce the use of modern TLS versions (TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3) and disable deprecated protocols and weak cipher suites to maintain strong encryption standards.

Manage Certificates Securely:

  • Utilize a centralized certificate management system to issue, renew, and revoke TLS certificates, ensuring that all certificates are valid and up-to-date.

Monitor and Audit TLS Usage:

  • Regularly review connection logs and perform security audits to verify that TLS encryption is properly enforced across all connections and to identify any potential misconfigurations.

References:

  • OWASP Transport Layer Protection Cheat Sheet

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Harden configuration and restrict network access
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that the Other Data Store is securely configured and that network access is strictly limited, reducing the system's exposure to potential attacks. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate secure configuration practices into their deployment processes and enforce robust network access controls through firewalls, security groups, or network ACLs. This approach minimizes vulnerabilities, limits the attack surface, and prevents unauthorized access.

Implementation Steps:

Harden Configuration:

  • Disable Unnecessary Services and Features: Remove or disable default settings, services, and features that are not required for your operations to reduce potential points of exploitation.
  • Apply Patches and Updates: Regularly update the database software and its underlying components to incorporate the latest security patches and best practices.
  • Secure Default Settings: Replace default credentials and modify out-of-the-box configurations to adhere to your organization's security policies.

Restrict Network Access:

  • Configure Firewalls and Security Groups: Limit access to the Other Data Store by defining rules that only allow traffic from trusted IP addresses and required ports.
  • Implement Network Segmentation: Place the database in a dedicated subnet or virtual network segment to isolate it from untrusted networks.
  • Monitor and Audit Access: Regularly review access logs and network traffic to detect and respond to unauthorized connection attempts or misconfigurations.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-123: Guide to General Server Security

countermeasure.name: Implement secure backup procedures with encryption and access controls
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that all backup processes for the Other Data Store are secure by encrypting backup data and restricting access to authorized personnel. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate secure backup procedures into the deployment and operational processes to safeguard data against unauthorized access, theft, or accidental loss.

Implementation Steps:

Automate and Schedule Secure Backups:

  • Configure automated backup jobs to run at regular intervals, ensuring data is consistently backed up without manual intervention.
  • Test backups periodically to verify data integrity and the effectiveness of restore procedures.

Encrypt Backup Data:

  • Encrypt Data at Rest: Use strong encryption standards (e.g., AES-256) to secure backup files stored on disk or in cloud storage.
  • Encrypt Data in Transit: Ensure backup data is encrypted during transmission using secure protocols (e.g., TLS) to prevent interception.

Enforce Access Controls:

  • Restrict Access: Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to limit backup access to authorized personnel only.
  • Audit Logging: Maintain logs of all backup operations and access attempts for traceability and forensic analysis.

Monitor and Manage Backup Security:

  • Utilize centralized management tools to enforce encryption policies and access controls consistently across backup environments.
  • Regularly review and audit backup configurations and access logs to detect and remediate any security anomalies.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-171

countermeasure.name: Implement strong authentication and role-based access control
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that only authenticated users with appropriate permissions can access the Other Data Store. By combining strong authentication measures with role-based access control (RBAC), developers and DevOps engineers can effectively minimize the risk of unauthorized access and potential data breaches.

Implementation Steps:

Implement Strong Authentication:

  • Enforce Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Require users to provide multiple forms of verification (e.g., password plus a one-time token) before granting access to the database.
  • Adopt Secure Authentication Protocols: Use industry-standard authentication protocols (e.g., OAuth 2.0, SAML, OpenID Connect) to securely manage user credentials.
  • Enforce Password Policies: Require strong, complex passwords and implement regular password updates to reduce the risk of compromise.

Establish Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

  • Define User Roles and Permissions: Create clear roles (e.g., administrator, developer, auditor) and assign the minimum necessary permissions to each role based on the principle of least privilege.
  • Integrate with Centralized Identity Management: Utilize a centralized identity and access management (IAM) system to manage user accounts, roles, and permissions across environments.
  • Automate Role Assignment and Provisioning: Implement automation tools to streamline the assignment, modification, and revocation of roles, ensuring that access is promptly updated as roles change.

Monitor and Audit Access:

  • Log Authentication and Access Events: Capture and analyze logs for all authentication and access activities to identify suspicious behavior or potential breaches.
  • Perform Regular Audits: Periodically review role assignments and access logs to ensure compliance with the least privilege principle and to promptly address any anomalies.

References:

  • OWASP Authentication Cheat Sheet

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)
PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: Regularly update the database to the latest secure version
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that your database remains protected against known vulnerabilities by keeping it up-to-date with the latest security patches and software versions. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate a robust update management process into the deployment and operational workflows to ensure that the database software is regularly evaluated, tested, and upgraded as new versions become available.

Implementation Steps:

Monitor Vendor Releases:

  • Subscribe to vendor security advisories and release notes to stay informed about new patches and updates.

Test and Validate Updates:

  • Validate updates in a staging environment before deploying them to production to ensure compatibility and stability.

Automate the Update Process:

  • Use configuration management tools (e.g., Ansible, Puppet, Chef) to automate the patching process and enforce consistent update policies across environments.

Establish a Regular Update Schedule:

  • Define and adhere to a regular maintenance window for applying updates and patches, ensuring minimal disruption to operations.

Maintain Rollback Mechanisms:

  • Develop and test rollback procedures to quickly revert to a previous version in case an update introduces unexpected issues.

Monitor and Audit:

  • Log and review update activities regularly to ensure compliance with security policies and to identify any anomalies.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-40 Revision 3: Guide to Enterprise Patch Management Technologies

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Use parameterized queries and validate inputs
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that the Other Data Store is protected against injection attacks, such as SQL injection, by enforcing the use of parameterized queries and rigorous input validation. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate these practices into their development workflows to ensure that user inputs are properly sanitized and handled as data rather than executable code.

Implementation Steps:

Use Parameterized Queries:

  • Implement Prepared Statements: Configure your database interactions to use prepared statements or parameterized queries, ensuring that user-supplied input is treated strictly as data.
  • Avoid String Concatenation: Do not construct SQL queries through string concatenation with user input, which can expose the system to injection attacks.

Validate Inputs:

  • Sanitize User Inputs: Validate and sanitize all incoming data against expected formats, lengths, and types using server-side validation techniques.
  • Apply Whitelisting: Use whitelisting approaches to allow only approved characters or patterns, thereby mitigating the risk of malicious input.

Test and Monitor:

  • Regular Code Reviews: Periodically review code to ensure adherence to safe query practices and input validation procedures.
  • Automate Security Testing: Integrate static and dynamic analysis tools to continuously assess and detect injection vulnerabilities.

References:

  • OWASP SQL Injection Prevention Cheat Sheet

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers exploit outdated vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Failure to regularly update the Other Database leaves known vulnerabilities unpatched, enabling attackers to exploit these weaknesses and compromise system security.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, and nation-state actors.
  • Vectors: Automated scans to detect outdated software, use of publicly available exploits, and leveraging SQL injection or remote code execution techniques.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized data access or data breaches.
  • System downtime or service disruption.
  • Compromise of data integrity and potential lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker uses an automated tool to scan for the database running an outdated version, then deploys a known exploit to execute remote code.
  2. A hacker exploits a known SQL injection vulnerability in an outdated system to extract sensitive customer data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers exploit misconfigurations in database settings
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Misconfigured database settingssuch as default credentials, improper access controls, or unsecured network endpointscan leave the system vulnerable, allowing attackers to gain unauthorized access, manipulate data, or disrupt services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and insider threats.
  • Vectors: Automated scans for default or weak configurations, brute force attacks on poorly secured accounts, and exploitation of unsecured network interfaces.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Data corruption or deletion.
  • Service disruptions and potential lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker identifies a database using default credentials and easily logs in to extract or alter data.
  2. A hacker exploits misconfigured network settings to bypass firewalls, gaining unauthorized administrative access to the database.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Attackers exfiltrate data due to insecure backup procedures
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Inadequate security measures in backup proceduressuch as lack of encryption and improper access controlscan expose sensitive data, allowing attackers to steal backup files and exfiltrate critical information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, insider threats, and state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors: Exploiting unsecured cloud storage, misconfigured backup systems, or weak access controls to gain unauthorized access to backup data.

Impacts:

  • Exposure of sensitive and confidential data.
  • Financial, legal, and reputational damage.
  • Non-compliance with regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker scans for publicly accessible cloud storage buckets, discovers unencrypted backup files, and downloads sensitive customer data.
  2. An insider abuses lax access controls on backup repositories to copy and exfiltrate confidential business information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service

threat.name: Attackers intercept data due to unencrypted communications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
When communications between clients and the Other Database occur without encryption, data transmitted over the network is exposed. This makes it susceptible to interception by attackers who can capture sensitive information in transit.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, and state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors: Utilizing packet sniffing tools on unencrypted networks, executing man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, and exploiting unsecured Wi-Fi or legacy communication protocols.

Impacts:

  • Exposure of sensitive or confidential data.
  • Potential identity theft, financial loss, and privacy breaches.
  • Increased risk of subsequent attacks due to compromised credentials.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker intercepts unencrypted traffic on a public Wi-Fi network, capturing login credentials and personal data during a client-to-database transaction.
  2. A man-in-the-middle attack is executed on a system that uses unencrypted HTTP connections, allowing the attacker to modify or eavesdrop on critical communications.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access due to weak authentication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Weak authentication mechanisms, such as the absence of multi-factor authentication, simple passwords, or outdated protocols, can enable attackers to bypass security controls and gain unauthorized access to the database. This compromises the integrity and confidentiality of the data stored.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and insider threats.
  • Vectors: Brute-force attacks, credential stuffing, social engineering, and exploitation of default or easily guessable credentials.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive or confidential data.
  • Data manipulation, exfiltration, or deletion.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within the network and subsequent security breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker uses automated tools to perform a brute-force attack on a database account protected by a weak password, eventually gaining administrative access.
  2. A hacker leverages stolen credentials from a previous breach to access the database, exploiting the absence of multi-factor authentication to bypass security measures.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers exploit SQL injection vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
SQL injection vulnerabilities occur when user input is improperly sanitized, allowing attackers to inject malicious SQL code into queries. This can lead to unauthorized data access, data manipulation, or complete system compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and script kiddies.
  • Vectors: Exploiting unsanitized input fields in web applications, abusing vulnerable API endpoints, and leveraging automated tools to identify and attack SQL injection flaws.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Data manipulation, deletion, or corruption.
  • Potential escalation of privileges and broader network compromise.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker inputs malicious SQL code into a web form that lacks proper sanitization, retrieving confidential customer records from the database.
  2. A hacker exploits a vulnerable API endpoint to inject SQL commands that alter or delete critical data, causing significant service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-272
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-272: Least Privilege Violation The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-668
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-668: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Activate audit logging and alerting for Power Apps activities
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center Documentation for detailed guidance on enabling audit logs and configuring alerts for app creation, modification, and usage.

Activate Audit Logging:

  • Enable detailed audit logging within the Power Platform Admin Center to capture events related to app creation, modification, and usage.
  • Ensure that audit logs capture critical data such as user identities, timestamps, and change details for thorough historical tracking and incident investigation.

Configure Alerting for Suspicious Activity:

  • Set up automated alerts within the admin center or integrate with a SIEM solution to detect and notify the security team of suspicious or abnormal behavior (e.g., unusual access patterns or unauthorized modifications).
  • Define specific thresholds and criteria for triggering alerts, ensuring that any significant deviations are promptly flagged for review and response.

Test and Validate:

  • Simulate a variety of app-related activities to confirm that the audit logs capture all relevant events accurately.
  • Validate that alerts are triggered correctly under suspicious conditions by testing with controlled scenarios.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously review audit logs and alert notifications as part of your centralized monitoring strategy to ensure timely detection of potential security incidents.
  • Periodically audit the logging and alert configuration settings to ensure compliance with evolving security policies and operational requirements.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center Documentation

countermeasure.name: Configure RBAC and granular permissions for Power Apps
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center Documentation for detailed guidance on configuring role-based access control and granular permissions in Power Apps.

Implement RBAC and Granular Permissions:

  • Define user roles based on business functions and assign the minimum permissions necessary for each role.
  • Update Power Apps security settings to enforce these roles, ensuring that users only have access to the applications and data required for their responsibilities.
  • Use built-in role assignments and permission settings in Power Apps and Microsoft Power Platform to manage access at a granular level.

Test and Validate:

  • Perform tests with user accounts representing different roles to verify that access limitations are correctly enforced.
  • Use audit logs to monitor access patterns and ensure that there are no excessive privileges granted inadvertently.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate role and permission change logs into your centralized monitoring or SIEM solution to detect any deviations from your defined access policies.
  • Periodically review and update your RBAC configuration to adapt to evolving security requirements and organizational changes.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center Documentation
  • Microsoft Power Platform Security Guidance

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS and Latest TLS for Power Apps
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Apps Security Guidance for detailed best practices on protecting data in transit.

Configure HTTPS and TLS Encryption:

  • Update the network and application configurations for Power Apps to ensure that all data transmissions occur over HTTPS.
  • Ensure that the latest version of TLS (e.g., TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3) is enabled and enforced for all connections to protect data in transit from interception and tampering.
  • Validate that any fallback to unsecured protocols is disabled to maintain strict encryption standards.

Test and Validate:

  • Use tools like SSL Labs and browser developer tools to confirm that all connections to Power Apps endpoints are secured via HTTPS and that TLS settings are current.
  • Perform periodic vulnerability scans and penetration testing to ensure there are no weak spots in the encryption configuration.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate monitoring solutions to continuously verify that secure connections are maintained and to alert on any deviations from the specified HTTPS/TLS configurations.
  • Schedule regular reviews of certificate expiry and TLS configurations to maintain alignment with evolving security standards.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Apps Security Guidance
  • Mozilla Developer Network on TLS

countermeasure.name: Implement DLP policies to restrict data access via connectors
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Platform Governance Documentation for detailed guidance on configuring Data Loss Prevention (DLP) policies, including restricting connector access and data sharing.

Implement DLP Policies:

  • Configure DLP policies within the Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center to specify which connectors can access or share sensitive data.
  • Create policy groups that enforce restrictions, ensuring only approved connectors can be used in flows and applications, thereby limiting the potential for data leakage or unauthorized sharing.
  • Define clear rules for data classification, allowed actions, and remediation processes when policy violations occur.

Test and Validate:

  • Simulate data transactions and connector usage scenarios to verify that the DLP policies are correctly enforced and that disallowed connectors are blocked from accessing sensitive data.
  • Review alerts and logs to ensure that any attempts to bypass the DLP policies are detected and appropriately handled.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate DLP monitoring into your centralized logging or SIEM system to continuously track connector activities and policy compliance.
  • Periodically audit the DLP policy configurations to ensure they remain effective and update them as needed in response to emerging security threats and organizational changes.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Platform Governance Documentation
  • Microsoft Power Platform Data Loss Prevention (DLP) Policies Overview

standard.ref: PM-17 Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information on External Systems

countermeasure.name: Integrate Microsoft Entra ID for secure authentication in Power Apps
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Apps Documentation for detailed guidance on integrating authentication mechanisms with Power Apps.

Integrate Microsoft Entra ID:

  • Update your Power Apps settings to configure integration with Microsoft Entra ID (formerly Azure Active Directory) to manage user identities centrally.
  • Use the built-in authentication connectors in Power Apps that leverage Microsoft Entra ID to enforce secure sign-in and role-based access control.
  • Ensure that the integration requires users to authenticate via strong methods (such as multi-factor authentication if configured) and that only authorized users are granted access to the app.

Test and Validate:

  • Verify that accessing the Power Apps application requires valid Microsoft Entra ID credentials by testing with both authorized and unauthorized accounts.
  • Review authentication logs to ensure that only users with the correct permissions can successfully sign in, and that any failed attempts are logged for further analysis.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously monitor authentication events and review access logs within your Power Platform and Microsoft Entra ID dashboards to quickly detect any suspicious activities.
  • Periodically audit the integration settings and update your authentication policies in line with evolving security standards and organizational requirements.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Apps Documentation
  • Microsoft Entra ID Overview
