countermeasure.name: Isolate development, testing, and production environments for Power Platform
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center Documentation for detailed guidance on creating and managing separate environments to prevent cross-contamination.

Implement Environment Isolation:

  • Establish distinct environments for development, testing, and production within your Power Platform setup.
  • Configure each environment with its own data sources, connectors, and security policies to ensure that changes in one environment do not impact the others.
  • Use environment-specific settings and access controls to enforce strict separation between these segments.

Test and Validate:

  • Verify that deployments in the development and testing environments do not affect production data or functionality.
  • Use automated testing tools and manual reviews to ensure that environment isolation is maintained consistently across all deployment stages.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Regularly review and audit environment configurations through the Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center to ensure that segregation is properly maintained.
  • Monitor access logs and environment activities to detect any unauthorized cross-environment activities or potential misconfigurations.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center Documentation
  • Microsoft Power Platform Governance

countermeasure.name: Store and manage application secrets with Azure Key Vault
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Apps Security Recommendations for detailed guidance on best practices for managing application secrets.

Implement Secure Secrets Management:

  • Deploy Azure Key Vault or use encrypted environment variables to securely store application secrets such as API keys, connection strings, and credentials.
  • Update your Power Apps configuration to retrieve secrets dynamically at runtime from the secure vault rather than embedding them directly in your code or configuration files.
  • Enforce strict access control and auditing policies on the vault to ensure that only authorized users and services can access these secrets.

Test and Validate:

  • Verify that your Power Apps application successfully retrieves secrets from Azure Key Vault and that secrets are not exposed in logs or configuration files.
  • Simulate unauthorized access attempts to confirm that access controls effectively protect stored secrets.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate Key Vault access logs with your centralized monitoring or SIEM system to continuously track and alert on any unauthorized access or anomalies.
  • Periodically review and update your secret management policies to ensure compliance with evolving security standards.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Apps Security Recommendations
  • Azure Key Vault Documentation

countermeasure.name: Validate and sanitize all user inputs in Power Apps
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Apps Best Practices documentation for detailed guidance on input validation and sanitization techniques.

Implement Input Validation and Sanitization:

  • Identify all user input fields and external data sources used in your Power Apps applications.
  • Implement input validation mechanisms that enforce data type, format, and length restrictions to ensure that user inputs match expected patterns.
  • Apply sanitization routines to cleanse any potentially malicious characters or code from user inputs before processing, thereby reducing the risk of injection attacks and data corruption.

Test and Validate:

  • Conduct comprehensive testing using both typical and malicious inputs to verify that the validation and sanitization procedures effectively block unsafe input.
  • Utilize automated security testing tools to simulate injection attacks and ensure that the application responds appropriately by rejecting any invalid data.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate input validation logs into your centralized monitoring or SIEM system to identify and track any repeated injection attempts or suspicious activities.
  • Periodically review and update input validation rules to remain aligned with emerging threats and evolving best practices.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Apps Best Practices
  • Microsoft Power Platform Security Guidance

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Overly permissive data access
threat.desc:
General threat description

When data access settings in Power Apps are too broad, users may inadvertently have access to sensitive or unrelated data. This can occur due to misconfigured permissions, lack of granular controls, or default settings that are overly lenient, increasing the risk of unauthorized data exposure and misuse.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Internal users who gain access to more data than required for their role.
  • Malicious insiders exploiting overly permissive access rights to extract confidential information.
  • External attackers who compromise user accounts with broad data permissions.
  • Misconfigured connectors or integrations that pull data from multiple sources without proper filtering.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized exposure or modification of sensitive data.
  • Increased risk of data breaches and compliance violations.
  • Potential misuse of confidential business information.
  • Escalation of insider threats through unmonitored access.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Unrestricted Group Access: A misconfigured Power Apps application allows users outside the targeted department to view sensitive financial data.
  2. Excessive API Permissions: An app integrated with multiple data sources grants broad access, enabling an attacker who gains entry through a compromised account to download proprietary data.
  3. Inadvertent Data Exposure: A developer deploys an app with default permission settings that inadvertently expose personal data of customers.
  4. Connector Misconfiguration: An integration connector pulls in more data than intended, giving a malicious insider access to critical business metrics.

threat.name: Insecure management of secrets
threat.desc:
General threat description

In Power Apps, secrets such as API keys, connection strings, and authentication tokens are used to integrate with external systems. If these secrets arent properly managedstored in plaintext, hardcoded in apps, or inadequately protectedthey can be exposed, leading to unauthorized access and manipulation of connected resources.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Malicious insiders or developers accessing poorly secured secrets.
  • External attackers exploiting vulnerable storage or transmission methods.
  • Misconfigured connectors inadvertently exposing sensitive credentials.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to data or external systems.
  • Manipulation of business processes and automation flows.
  • Data breaches and compliance violations.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within integrated systems.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Plaintext Storage: Secrets are stored in app code or configuration files without encryption, allowing an attacker who gains access to the codebase to retrieve sensitive credentials.
  2. Exposed Connectors: A misconfigured connector leaks API tokens used in Power Apps, enabling unauthorized integration with critical external services.
  3. Hardcoded Secrets: A developer hardcodes connection strings into an app shared across the organization, and a compromised account is used to extract these secrets, opening doors to further exploitation.

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring and auditing
threat.desc:
General threat description

Lack of robust monitoring and auditing in Power Apps can result in undetected misconfigurations, unauthorized access, or suspicious activities. Without proper log collection and real-time alerting, security incidents may go unnoticed, impeding timely response and forensic analysis.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Malicious insiders leveraging weak audit trails to perform unauthorized actions.
  • External attackers exploiting compromised accounts to manipulate apps without detection.
  • Automation and integration issues where changes in flows are not tracked.
  • Unintentional misconfigurations that escape notice due to inadequate logging.

Impacts

  • Delayed detection and response to security breaches.
  • Difficulty in conducting forensic investigations after incidents.
  • Higher risk of data leakage or unauthorized changes going unmitigated.
  • Potential regulatory compliance failures due to incomplete audit trails.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Data Access: An attacker uses stolen credentials to modify sensitive app data, and due to insufficient logging, the breach goes undetected until significant damage occurs.
  2. Misuse of Flows: A malicious insider alters a critical business flow to exfiltrate data. Lack of detailed audit logs delays discovery and remediation.
  3. Integration Exploitation: An automated integration misconfiguration triggers unintended data transfers without generating meaningful alerts, allowing persistent exposure.
  4. Compliance Audit Failure: During a regulatory audit, incomplete logs hinder the organizations ability to demonstrate proper control over changes and access in Power Apps.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1556.004 - Network Device Authentication

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmissions
threat.desc:
General threat description

In Power Apps, data flows between apps, connectors, and external systems. When these transmissions occur without encryption (e.g., using unsecured protocols or weak TLS configurations), sensitive information is exposed to interception and tampering during transit.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Network-based attackers capturing plaintext data via sniffing or eavesdropping.
  • Man-in-the-middle (MitM) attackers intercepting unencrypted API calls and data flows.
  • Misconfigured integrations that default to non-secure communication channels.

Impacts

  • Exposure of confidential and sensitive data such as credentials and business information.
  • Unauthorized data modification or injection during transmission.
  • Increased risk of compliance breaches and reputational damage.
  • Facilitated lateral movement and escalation if intercepted data is exploited.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Intercepted API Calls: An attacker on a public Wi-Fi network intercepts API calls from a Power Apps connector transmitting data without TLS.
  2. Data Injection: A man-in-the-middle exploits an unencrypted channel to modify transaction data, compromising workflow integrity.
  3. Credential Theft: Unencrypted authentication data is captured from a misconfigured endpoint, enabling an attacker to access sensitive resources.

threat.name: Inadequate environment segmentation
threat.desc:
General threat description

When development, testing, and production environments arent properly isolated, sensitive production data may be exposed or accidentally modified. This lack of clear boundaries increases the risk of unauthorized access or erroneous deployment across environments.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Malicious insiders or developers leveraging access to lower-security environments.
  • External attackers exploiting misconfigured environment controls.
  • Accidental misuse by users with overlapping permissions across environments.

Impacts

  • Exposure and leakage of sensitive production data.
  • Unauthorized changes to live applications.
  • Compliance violations and potential financial loss.
  • Accidental deployment of untested code to production.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Data crossover: A developer using the same credentials in both development and production unintentionally accesses confidential data.
  2. Misconfigured controls: Loose access settings in a test environment let an insider pivot into production.
  3. Accidental deployment: Unclear boundaries cause test changes to be mistakenly pushed into production, corrupting live data.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Inadequate authentication controls
threat.desc:
General threat description

When authentication mechanisms in Power Apps are weaksuch as simple passwords, lack of multi-factor authentication (MFA), or misconfigured identity integrationsunauthorized users may gain access to apps and their underlying data. This vulnerability increases the risk of data breaches, manipulation of app functionality, and wider unauthorized access across integrated systems.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers using brute-force or credential stuffing techniques.
  • Phishing campaigns that harvest user credentials.
  • Compromised or misconfigured identity integrations (e.g., SSO or OAuth) that fail to enforce strong controls.
  • Malicious insiders exploiting overly permissive authentication settings.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data and critical business processes.
  • Potential data breaches, leading to reputational and financial damage.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement across systems connected via Power Apps.
  • Compliance and regulatory issues stemming from weak protection of confidential information.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Brute-force Attack: An attacker uses automated tools against weak passwords, eventually compromising an account that accesses sensitive Power Apps workflows.
  2. Phishing Incident: A user is tricked into revealing their credentials through a phishing email; without MFA, the attacker gains unfettered access to the associated Power Apps.
  3. Misconfigured SSO: A misconfigured single sign-on integration inadvertently grants excessive privileges, allowing an unauthorized user to access multiple business applications.
  4. Credential Stuffing: Compromised credentials from a different breach are reused to access Power Apps due to lack of proper authentication controls, resulting in unauthorized data exposure.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure data validation
threat.desc:
General threat description

In Microsoft Power Apps, data validation is critical to ensure that inputs from users or external systems conform to expected formats and constraints. Insecure or insufficient validation may allow malicious or malformed data to enter the system, potentially leading to injection attacks, data corruption, or unintended application behavior.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers submitting crafted inputs to exploit application vulnerabilities.
  • Malicious insiders using manipulated data to bypass application logic.
  • Automated tools generating abnormal inputs to trigger failures or inject harmful payloads.
  • Misconfigured connectors that fail to properly validate incoming data before processing.

Impacts

  • Execution of injection attacks (e.g., SQL injection or code injection) leading to unauthorized data access.
  • Corruption of data stored within the system or disruption of business process flows.
  • Unintended behavior or system crashes due to processing invalid inputs.
  • Potential compromise of sensitive information and violation of compliance requirements.

Example attack scenarios

  1. SQL Injection: An attacker inputs specially crafted strings into a data entry field that is not properly sanitized, allowing them to manipulate underlying database queries.
  2. Script Injection: Malicious code is inserted into a form input field that lacks robust validation, causing the execution of unintended scripts when the data is displayed.
  3. Business Logic Bypass: An attacker exploits weak validation in a workflow to bypass approval controls, thereby triggering unauthorized actions.
  4. Connector Exploitation: A misconfigured external service connector fails to validate incoming data, enabling an attacker to inject payloads that disrupt the flow or exfiltrate data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-116
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-116: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output The product prepares a structured message for communication with another component, but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result, the intended structure of the message is not preserved.

weakness.name: CWE-272
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-272: Least Privilege Violation The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Activate audit logs and alerts for Power Automate flows
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center Logging and Monitoring Documentation for detailed guidance on configuring audit logs and setting up alerts.

Activate Audit Logging:

  • Configure Power Automate to record audit logs for flow creation, modification, and run history within the Power Platform admin center.
  • Ensure that relevant events, including flow updates and execution history, are captured and stored securely for compliance and investigation purposes.

Configure Alerts:

  • Set up automated alerts within the admin center or using integrated monitoring solutions to notify security teams of suspicious activities such as unauthorized modifications, unusual flow executions, or abnormal run histories.
  • Define alert thresholds and escalation procedures so that any potential security incidents trigger prompt responses.

Test and Validate:

  • Simulate flow creation, modification, and execution scenarios to verify that audit logs are correctly generated and that alerts are triggered appropriately.
  • Regularly review log and alert data to ensure that the monitoring system is effectively detecting and notifying on suspicious activities.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously monitor audit logs and alert notifications as part of your centralized logging or SIEM system.
  • Periodically review and refine the logging settings and alert rules to adapt to changes in flow usage patterns and emerging security threats.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center Logging and Monitoring Documentation
  • Microsoft Power Platform Security Overview

countermeasure.name: Assign minimal permissions for flows and access control
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center Documentation for best practices on managing access levels and enforcing minimal permissions.

Configure Minimal Permissions:

  • Define and assign the least privileges necessary for users who manage and run flows, ensuring that only authorized actions are permitted.
  • Carefully manage user roles and access levels within the Power Platform Admin Center to restrict data exposure.
  • Utilize role-based access control (RBAC) policies to regularly review and adjust permissions based on job responsibilities and operational needs.

Test and Validate:

  • Conduct tests with various user accounts to confirm that access levels are limited as intended and that flows operate without exposing sensitive data.
  • Monitor logs and user activity to verify that any deviations from the defined access controls are detected promptly.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate access logs into your centralized monitoring or SIEM system for continuous tracking of user activities.
  • Periodically review and update access control policies to align with evolving security requirements and ensure that only the minimal required permissions are granted.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center Documentation
  • Microsoft 365 Compliance Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enforce encrypted on-premises data gateway for secure data transfer
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Automate Documentation for detailed guidance on configuring the on-premises data gateway and its encryption features.

Configure the On-Premises Data Gateway:

  • Install and configure the on-premises data gateway with encryption enabled, ensuring that all data transmitted between cloud flows and on-premises resources is securely encrypted.
  • Verify that the gateway settings enforce encryption standards (such as TLS) for data in transit.
  • Ensure that the configuration aligns with your overall network security policies and that encryption keys are managed securely.

Test and Validate:

  • Simulate data transfers between cloud flows and on-premises resources to confirm that the encryption is active and all data is transmitted securely.
  • Use network monitoring tools to verify that no unencrypted data is being transmitted through the gateway.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate gateway logs into your centralized monitoring or SIEM system to track encrypted traffic and detect any anomalies in data transfer.
  • Periodically review the configuration and update it as needed to keep up with emerging encryption standards and security best practices.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Automate Documentation
  • Microsoft On-Premises Data Gateway Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS for all connectors and data transfers in Power Automate
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Automate Security Guidance for detailed best practices on using secure connectors and data transfers.

Configure HTTPS/TLS Encryption:

  • Update all Power Automate connectors and integration points to ensure they use HTTPS or TLS-encrypted connections for every data transfer.
  • Disable any unencrypted communication protocols and enforce encryption across all automated workflows to protect data in transit.
  • Validate that legacy or custom connectors are modified to comply with this encryption policy.

Test and Validate:

  • Utilize network monitoring tools or API testing utilities to confirm that data transfers occur over secure encrypted channels.
  • Perform end-to-end tests of your automated flows to verify that no data is transmitted unencrypted.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously monitor your network traffic and Power Automate logs to ensure that all connections remain encrypted.
  • Periodically review connector configurations and audit logs to detect and remediate any deviations from the established security settings.

countermeasure.name: Enforce multi-factor authentication for Power Automate users
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Platform Documentation for detailed guidance on implementing multi-factor authentication (MFA) for enhanced security.

Configure MFA for Power Automate:

  • Update your Microsoft Power Platform or Microsoft Entra ID (formerly Azure Active Directory) settings to require MFA for all Power Automate users and connections.
  • Ensure that MFA is enforced during sign-in and before accessing or modifying flows, thus reducing the risk of unauthorized flow creation or modifications.
  • Configure conditional access policies to enforce MFA in high-risk scenarios or based on user context.

Test and Validate:

  • Perform tests using both compliant and non-compliant accounts to verify that MFA is properly enforced across all Power Automate endpoints.
  • Monitor authentication logs to ensure that MFA challenges are being triggered and that unauthorized access attempts are blocked.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously integrate authentication logs into your centralized monitoring or SIEM system to detect any anomalies in sign-in patterns.
  • Periodically review MFA configurations and conditional access policies to ensure they remain aligned with evolving security standards and organizational requirements.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Platform Documentation
  • Microsoft Entra ID Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enforce secure secrets management for flows
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Automate Security Best Practices for detailed guidance on managing secrets securely within automated flows.

Implement Secure Secrets Management:

  • Configure your flows to retrieve sensitive information from Azure Key Vault or utilize Microsoft Encrypted environment variables instead of embedding credentials directly into flow configurations.
  • Ensure that your vault integration is set up with strict access controls, and that secrets are encrypted both at rest and in transit.
  • Use role-based access controls (RBAC) to limit who can update or access the stored secrets.

Test and Validate:

  • Verify that flows successfully retrieve the necessary secrets from the designated secure storage without exposing sensitive information in logs or configuration files.
  • Simulate attempted access by unauthorized users to confirm that access to the secrets is effectively restricted.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate logging and monitoring of vault access and environment variable usage into your centralized security system or SIEM to track any anomalies.
  • Periodically audit the access and update policies for your secrets management solution to ensure ongoing compliance with security standards.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Automate Security Best Practices
  • Azure Key Vault Documentation

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

countermeasure.name: Implement DLP policies for Power Platform connectors
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Platform Governance Documentation for detailed guidance on implementing DLP policies and managing connector access.

Implement DLP Policies:

  • Define Data Loss Prevention (DLP) policies that specify which connectors are allowed to access or share data.
  • Create policy groups in the Power Platform admin center to restrict unapproved connectors and segregate data by sensitivity.
  • Apply these DLP policies to your environments and flows so that only authorized connectors can be used to access or transfer sensitive data.

Test and Validate:

  • Verify that the DLP policies correctly block or restrict data sharing through unapproved connectors by simulating data transfers in a test environment.
  • Review alert logs and reports to ensure that policy violations are flagged and that the restrictions are effectively enforced.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate DLP alert logs with your centralized monitoring system or SIEM to continuously track connector usage and policy compliance.
  • Periodically review and update DLP policies and connector lists to remain aligned with evolving organizational security requirements and data protection standards.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Platform Governance Documentation
  • Microsoft Power Platform Data Loss Prevention (DLP) Policies Overview

standard.ref: PM-17 Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information on External Systems

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Restrict unverified connectors for Power Platform flows
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center documentation for detailed guidance on managing connectors and enforcing security policies.

Configure Connector Restrictions:

  • Configure the Power Platform Admin Center settings to restrict or disable the use of unverified or custom connectors unless they have undergone a proper vetting process.
  • Establish a whitelist of approved connectors and enforce policies that require thorough security reviews for any custom connectors before they can be enabled.
  • Disable default access to unverified connectors across your organization to mitigate risks from potential vulnerabilities or malicious behavior.

Test and Validate:

  • In a controlled test environment, attempt to add and utilize both verified and unverified connectors to ensure that the restrictions are properly enforced.
  • Verify that only connectors on the approved list are accessible and that any attempt to use an unverified connector is blocked or prompts for review.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate connector usage logs with your centralized monitoring or SIEM solution to continuously track and review connector activity.
  • Periodically audit the list of approved connectors and review any exceptions or unauthorized attempts, adjusting policies as necessary to address emerging threats.

References:

  • Microsoft Power Platform Admin Center

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive privileges and data leakage
threat.desc:
General threat description

When users or automation flows in Power Automate are granted more privileges than needed, they may access or transmit sensitive data unintentionally or maliciously. Overprivileged accounts and misconfigured connectors can lead to data exposure and unauthorized sharing across integrated systems.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Overprivileged internal users misconfiguring flows.
  • Malicious insiders or attackers exploiting high-privilege accounts.
  • Misconfigured integration connectors exposing broader data sets.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized disclosure of confidential data.
  • Regulatory non-compliance and reputational harm.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within systems.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A high-privilege user creates a flow that inadvertently collects and shares sensitive HR data.
  2. A compromised account reconfigures automation flows to exfiltrate proprietary financial information.
  3. Misconfigured connectors allow a malicious insider to download critical customer records.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General threat description

Flows and connectors in Power Automate may transmit sensitive information between applications and services. When these transmissions occur without proper encryption (e.g., using unencrypted protocols or weak cipher suites), attackers can intercept or manipulate the data in transit, leading to unauthorized disclosure and data leakage.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Network-based attackers using packet sniffers to capture plaintext data.
  • Man-in-the-middle (MitM) attackers intercepting unencrypted API calls or connector communications.
  • Compromised network devices or misconfigured endpoints that downgrade secure connections.
  • Insecure integration configurations that default to non-encrypted channels.

Impacts

  • Exposure of sensitive data such as credentials, personal information, or corporate secrets.
  • Unauthorized data manipulation, leading to integrity issues.
  • Increased risk of regulatory and compliance violations.
  • Potential for cascading security breaches due to intercepted or altered data.

Example attack scenarios

  1. API Call Interception: An attacker on a shared network intercepts unencrypted API calls from a Power Automate flow, capturing sensitive customer data.
  2. Connector Vulnerability Exploit: A misconfigured connector transmits data without encryption, allowing a man-in-the-middle to alter data before it reaches the destination service.
  3. Bypass of Encryption: A compromised network device forces a downgrade to an unencrypted protocol, exposing sensitive configuration or transactional data used by the flow.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information

threat.name: Insecure secrets management
threat.desc:
General threat description

In Power Automate, secretssuch as API keys, tokens, and credentialsare used in automation flows to integrate with various services. If these secrets are stored or transmitted insecurely (e.g., in plaintext or unprotected environment variables), they may be exposed, leading to unauthorized access and manipulation of automated workflows.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Malicious insiders accessing poorly protected secrets.
  • External attackers exploiting insecure storage or transmission mechanisms.
  • Misconfigured connectors inadvertently exposing secrets through integration points.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to connected systems and sensitive data.
  • Manipulation of automation flows to exfiltrate data or disrupt operations.
  • Compliance breaches due to the exposure of regulated information.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement across integrated systems.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Plaintext Storage: Secrets hardcoded in flow configurations or stored in unencrypted environment variables are retrieved by an attacker who gains access to the automation environment.
  2. Misconfigured Connectors: A connector configured with overly permissive settings exposes its authentication token, allowing unauthorized modifications to workflows and data access.
  3. Inadequate Transmission Security: Secrets transmitted between Power Automate and third-party services over unencrypted channels are intercepted by a man-in-the-middle attacker.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552.001 - Credentials In Files

threat.name: Insecure connector usage
threat.desc:
General threat description

Power Automate relies on connectors to integrate with third-party services and internal systems. If these connectors are configured insecurelysuch as using weak authentication, broad permissions, or untrusted endpointsattackers or malicious insiders may exploit them to access, modify, or exfiltrate sensitive data.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Malicious insiders exploiting overly permissive connector settings.
  • External attackers compromising connectors through weak authentication or vulnerabilities.
  • Misconfigurations that inadvertently expose data to untrusted endpoints.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to or manipulation of sensitive data from connected systems.
  • Data leakage across integrated applications.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within the organizations network.
  • Compliance issues due to exposure of regulated data.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Weak authentication on a connector allows an attacker to gain access to confidential customer records from a linked CRM system.
  2. Overly broad permissions in a connector provide access to sensitive financial data, which is then misused by a malicious insider.
  3. Misconfigured endpoints in a connector result in data being sent to an untrusted third party, leading to data leakage.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring and auditing
threat.desc:
General threat description

Without robust monitoring and auditing of Power Automate flows and connectors, unauthorized activities or misconfigurations may go undetected. This gap reduces the ability to identify misuse, trace incidents, and enforce compliance standards, ultimately delaying remediation.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Malicious insiders exploiting gaps in activity logging to modify or exfiltrate data.
  • External attackers using compromised accounts to manipulate flows without detection.
  • Automated abuse that generates anomalous behavior not captured by minimal logging.
  • Misconfigured integrations that bypass or disable audit trails.

Impacts

  • Delayed detection and response to security incidents.
  • Inability to perform effective forensic investigations.
  • Increased risk of data leakage, unauthorized access, and compliance violations.
  • Undermined accountability and persistent exposure of vulnerabilities.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Undetected Flow Modification: An attacker uses a compromised account to alter a critical automation flow. Due to insufficient logging, the changes go unnoticed until significant data exfiltration occurs.
  2. Silent Misuse of Connectors: A malicious insider leverages unmonitored connectors to access sensitive data across integrated systems without triggering alerts.
  3. API Abuse: Automated attacks exploit weak monitoring controls to repeatedly trigger flows that exfiltrate data, with no audit trail to correlate the activity.
  4. Compliance Breach: A failure to log key access events results in undetected data sharing with unauthorized parties, leading to regulatory penalties.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Inadequate authentication controls
threat.desc:
General threat description

When authentication mechanisms in Power Automate are weaksuch as using simple passwords, lacking multi-factor authentication (MFA), or misconfigured identity integrationsunauthorized users can gain access to critical workflows and sensitive data. This vulnerability increases the risk of unauthorized manipulation or exfiltration of data across connected systems.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers using brute-force techniques or credential stuffing to exploit weak login credentials.
  • Malicious insiders or compromised accounts abusing overly permissive authentication controls.
  • Phishing campaigns that harvest login credentials and, in the absence of MFA, enable unauthorized access.
  • Misconfigured identity integrations (e.g., SSO, OAuth) that fail to enforce strong authentication standards.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive automation flows and connected systems.
  • Increased risk of data exfiltration, unauthorized modifications, and malicious workflow alterations.
  • Elevated potential for lateral movement across the organizations network.
  • Compliance and regulatory issues due to inadequate protection of confidential information.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Brute-Force Attack: An attacker uses automated tools to guess weak passwords for accounts with access to Power Automate, gaining control over critical workflows.
  2. Phishing Incident: A targeted phishing campaign successfully collects user credentials, and without MFA, the attacker exploits these to access sensitive automated processes.
  3. Misconfigured SSO: Faulty integration with an SSO provider results in overly broad access rights, inadvertently granting unauthorized users administrative privileges in Power Automate.
  4. Token Reuse: An expired session token is not properly invalidated, allowing attackers to replay authentication tokens and access automation workflows without additional verification.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Inadequate flow governance
threat.desc:
General threat description

Weak governance over automation flows in Power Automatesuch as lack of flow validation, insufficient access controls, and absence of periodic reviewscan lead to the proliferation of unvetted, error-prone, or malicious flows. This creates risks of unauthorized access, data leakage, and unintended actions across connected systems.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Internal users or departments creating flows without proper oversight or adherence to policy.
  • Malicious insiders designing unauthorized or harmful flows.
  • Compromised accounts introducing flows that bypass governance controls.
  • Automation bypasses due to lack of standardized approval and audit procedures.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized or erroneous workflows that exfiltrate, modify, or delete sensitive data.
  • Increased attack surface via flows that integrate with critical systems.
  • Compliance and audit failures due to an unregulated flow ecosystem.
  • Operational inefficiencies and potential disruptions caused by conflicting or poorly designed flows.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Unreviewed Flow Deployment: A department deploys a flow to auto-share confidential data externally without proper review, leading to inadvertent data leakage.
  2. Malicious Flow Creation: A compromised account creates a flow that scrapes sensitive information from connected systems and exfiltrates it to an external source.
  3. Inconsistent Policy Enforcement: Inadequate governance allows duplicate or conflicting flows that, when executed, cause unauthorized actions or resource contention.
  4. Outdated Flow Usage: Flows with outdated or flawed logic remain active due to a lack of regular audits, causing unintended data modifications or privacy violations.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-502
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-502: Deserialization of Untrusted Data The product deserializes untrusted data without sufficiently verifying that the resulting data will be valid.

weakness.name: CWE-668
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-668: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

weakness.name: CWE-74
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-74: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Output Used by a Downstream Component ('Injection') The product constructs all or part of a command, data structure, or record using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify how it is parsed or interpreted when it is sent to a downstream component. Software or other automated logic has certain assumptions about what constitutes data and control respectively. It is the lack of verification of these assumptions for user-controlled input that leads to injection problems. Injection problems encompass a wide variety of issues -- all mitigated in very different ways and usually attempted in order to alter the control flow of the process. For this reason, the most effective way to discuss these weaknesses is to note the distinct features that classify them as injection weaknesses. The most important issue to note is that all injection problems share one thing in common -- i.e., they allow for the injection of control plane data into the user-controlled data plane. This means that the execution of the process may be altered by sending code in through legitimate data channels, using no other mechanism. While buffer overflows, and many other flaws, involve the use of some further issue to gain execution, injection problems need only for the data to be parsed.

weakness.name: CWE-755
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-755: Improper Handling of Exceptional Conditions The product does not handle or incorrectly handles an exceptional condition.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Implement proper parsing and input validation
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure the security of your server-side web service, including REST APIs and gRPC services, by implementing effective parsing and input validation. Proper execution of these practices prevents security vulnerabilities such as injection attacks, buffer overflows, and other forms of malicious input manipulation. The following steps, designed for developers with no previous security experience, provide a guideline to implement these measures:

Steps for Robust Parsing and Input Validation:
  • Enforce strict input validation checks. Verify that all user-provided data matches the expected format, length, and data type. Employ regular expressions for the validation of complex input patterns, ensuring that data conforms to predefined formats.
  • Adopt a whitelisting approach for input validation. Explicitly define and accept only known, safe input patterns, rather than attempting to identify and block potentially harmful inputs.
  • Handle special characters with care, especially in contexts where they might be interpreted as executable or control characters. This step is crucial for preventing injection attacks.
  • Utilize input sanitization techniques. Employ encoding or proper filtering strategies to neutralize or strip out potentially dangerous characters or patterns from user inputs.
  • Employ established libraries and tools for their robust input validation and parsing features. This approach minimizes the risk of errors that could lead to vulnerabilities.
  • Implement both client-side and server-side validation to improve user experience by providing immediate feedback through client-side validation, while relying on server-side validation as the ultimate enforcement point to ensure security.
  • Develop secure error-handling practices. Ensure that error messages do not disclose sensitive information that could be exploited by attackers.
  • Incorporate automated tools for scanning and testing your application regularly. This helps in early detection and fixing of potential issues related to input validation and parsing.

By following these actionable steps and adhering to good security practices, you can significantly reduce the risk of security breaches and vulnerabilities in your web service. Regularly update your knowledge on security best practices and tools from reliable sources such as the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) to stay ahead of potential threats.

reference.name: Input Validation Cheat Sheet

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Implement service restrictions
countermeasure.desc:
Implement service restrictions effectively to safeguard your server-side web service, including REST APIs and gRPC services, against unauthorized use and potential security threats. Follow these actionable steps, designed even for developers with no prior security background, to mitigate risks such as brute force attacks, denial-of-service (DoS) attempts, and unwarranted resource consumption.

Implementing Rate Limiting and Service Restrictions:
  • Introduce rate-limiting mechanisms. Use a library or module specific to your development framework to limit the number of requests a user or client can make within a given timeframe. This measure is crucial for preventing overuse and abuse of the service.
  • Establish granular rate limits for various actions or API endpoints. Analyze the functionality and sensitivity of different parts of your service to apply more stringent limits where necessary. For instance, login attempts may require stricter limits compared to general data retrieval operations.
  • Set time windows for rate limiting that reflect the expected traffic patterns. Shorter windows can prevent burst traffic from causing harm, while longer windows prevent sustained high usage. Adjust these windows based on real-world usage data and analytics.
  • Consider implementing graceful degradation strategies. During peak loads or detected attacks, dynamically adjust rate limits or temporarily degrade service for non-critical functionalities to ensure availability of core features.
  • Use whitelisting and blacklisting to control access. Allow trusted clients or users unfettered access by whitelisting their IPs or accounts, and blacklist entities that exhibit malicious behavior or violate usage policies.
  • Deploy comprehensive monitoring and logging. Utilize tools and practices that enable you to observe traffic in real-time, recognize patterns indicative of abuse, and maintain records for investigating security incidents.
  • Incorporate additional security layers. Integrate solutions like Web Application Firewalls (WAFs) and Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) to defend against a broader spectrum of threats, including sophisticated DoS and DDoS attacks.

Refer to reputable security frameworks and guidelines, such as those provided by OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project), to further enhance your service's security posture. Staying informed about the latest security best practices and vulnerabilities in web services is crucial for maintaining a robust defense against evolving threats.

reference.name: What is Rate Limiting? How it works and implementation techniques

countermeasure.name: Limit information leakage, e.g., via hardened configuration
countermeasure.desc:
Limiting information leakage in your server-side web service, such as a REST API or a gRPC service, is crucial to protect sensitive information from being exposed through various channels like error messages, system logs, or misconfigurations. Follow these actionable steps to harden your service's configuration against unintended data exposure, suitable for developers without previous security experience:

Key Strategies to Limit Information Leakage:
  • Display minimalistic error messages that do not reveal internal details about the service's structure or state. Error messages should be generic enough to inform the user of the problem without disclosing sensitive information.
  • Alter default configurations immediately after service setup to ensure that security settings are optimized and not left at their less secure, default state.
  • Restrict access to the service and its logs strictly to authorized personnel. Ensure that administrative interfaces and log files are not accessible to unauthorized users.
  • Apply data masking techniques for outputs that may display sensitive information. This is especially important for personal or financial data to prevent direct exposure to unauthorized viewers.
  • Configure network settings and firewalls diligently to close off unnecessary open ports and correct misconfigured services that might inadvertently expose sensitive data.
  • Implement Content Security Policies (CSP) to restrict what resources can be loaded and executed by the service, reducing the risk of data leakage via XSS attacks or other vector exploits.
  • Manage file and directory permissions meticulously to prevent unauthorized access to files containing sensitive information. Only essential access rights should be granted, based on the principle of least privilege.
  • Encrypt sensitive data in transit and at rest. Utilizing strong encryption methods ensures that, even if data is somehow accessed, it remains unintelligible without the decryption keys.

Adhering to these steps not only enhances your web service's security posture but also aligns with good security practices recommended by leading security organizations, such as OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project). Regularly review and update your service's configurations to adapt to evolving security threats and protect against information leakage.

reference.name: A05:2021 Security Misconfiguration

countermeasure.name: Secure communication channels, e.g., use TLS
countermeasure.desc:
Securing communication channels is critical for any server-side web service, such as REST APIs and gRPC services, to protect data from eavesdropping, tampering, and unauthorized access. Implementing Transport Layer Security (TLS) is a foundational step towards achieving this goal. Here are actionable steps to ensure secure communication through TLS, suitable for developers without previous security experience:

Steps for Implementing TLS:
  • Adopt the latest version of TLS (e.g., TLS 1.2 or higher) to leverage advanced security features and address vulnerabilities found in older versions.
  • Ensure digital certificates used for TLS are properly managed. Certificates should be signed by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA), kept up-to-date, and renewed regularly.
  • Select strong and secure cipher suites for the service configuration, which are essential for providing effective encryption, key exchange, and authentication.
  • Enable Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) to guarantee that each session's encryption keys are unique and cannot be compromised even if the long-term keys are.
  • Implement HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) to force web browsers to establish connections only over HTTPS, minimizing the risk of downgrade attacks.
  • Create a protocol for continuous monitoring and auditing of your TLS settings to quickly identify and fix any vulnerabilities or configuration errors.
  • For services requiring authentication, configure TLS to request and validate client certificates during the handshake, enhancing mutual authentication.
  • Practice secure key management to protect the confidentiality and integrity of cryptographic keys involved in the TLS process.

By following these guidelines and incorporating security best practices into your development and deployment processes, you can significantly strengthen the security of your web service. Regular updates and audits of your TLS configuration, in line with recommendations from security experts and organizations such as the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP), are crucial for maintaining a high level of protection against emerging threats.

countermeasure.name: Use secure methods to handle secrets and other sensitive information
countermeasure.desc:
Protecting secrets and other sensitive information is paramount for any server-side web service, including REST APIs and gRPC services, to prevent unauthorized access and data breaches. Follow these actionable steps to securely manage such critical data, suitable even for developers without prior security experience:

Secure Handling of Secrets and Sensitive Information:
  • Securely store sensitive data by avoiding plaintext storage of passwords and employing strong encryption mechanisms for all sensitive information.
  • Utilize secure credential vaults or management systems for centralizing the protection of sensitive data. These tools offer encryption, stringent access controls, and auditing capabilities to safeguard secrets.
  • Ensure the secure generation, storage, and transmission of API keys or tokens. Communicate over secure protocols like HTTPS to protect the integrity and confidentiality of these credentials.
  • Adopt a regular rotation policy for all secrets, such as passwords, API keys, and tokens, to mitigate the risk of old credentials being exploited.
  • Encrypt all secrets during transit between different components of your service, ensuring they are not exposed to eavesdropping or interception.
  • For password transmission, always use HTTPS and avoid including passwords in URL parameters. Implement secure password hashing and salting techniques to protect stored passwords.
  • Apply strict access control measures to limit access to sensitive information, adhering to the principle of least privilege. Ensure users and services have only the access necessary for their function.
  • Maintain sensitive configuration files securely and separately from the codebase to prevent accidental exposure. Avoid hardcoding secrets in source code.
  • Set up auditing and monitoring to quickly detect unauthorized attempts to access sensitive information and to ensure compliance with security policies.
  • When deploying services, carefully handle the transfer of secrets to production environments to prevent leakage or exposure during the deployment phase.

By adhering to these guidelines and incorporating security best practices from authoritative sources like OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project), you can significantly enhance the security posture of your web service, protecting it and its users from potential threats.

countermeasure.name: Use strong authentication mechanisms
countermeasure.desc:
Secure your server-side web service, be it a REST API or a gRPC service, by implementing robust authentication mechanisms. This will ensure that only authorized users or systems can access and interact with your service. Here are actionable steps that developers, even those without prior security knowledge, can follow to strengthen authentication:

Key Steps to Enhance Authentication:
  • Adopt multi-factor authentication (MFA). For APIs, combine traditional methods like API keys or client credentials with dynamic security tokens that change periodically, adding an extra layer of security.
  • Utilize industry-standard authentication and authorization protocols such as OAuth and OpenID Connect. These protocols provide a secure and standardized way for clients to request and use access tokens effectively safeguarding access to your services.
  • Implement strong password policies. Enforce rules on password complexity, such as minimum length, inclusion of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and symbols, and mandate regular password updates.
  • Follow secure session management practices. Use secure, randomly generated session identifiers, enforce session expiration after a period of inactivity, and protect against session hijacking attacks.
  • Consider adaptive authentication methods that gauge the authentication requirements based on context, like the user's location, device, or the sensitivity of the operation being requested.
  • For machine-to-machine interactions or when strong client authentication is necessary, use client certificate authentication. This ensures that only clients with a valid certificate can establish connections.
  • Deploy account lockout mechanisms to lock or suspend user accounts after several unsuccessful login attempts, protecting against brute-force attacks.
  • Ensure secure transmission of credentials using encrypted channels, preferably HTTPS, to protect data in transit.
  • Maintain secure user account management. Regularly review user access privileges, promptly deactivate inactive accounts, and immediately revoke access for users who leave the organization or whose accounts are compromised.
  • Enable detailed logging and monitoring of authentication attempts to identify and investigate suspicious activities promptly.

Following these steps and adhering to established security practices, such as those recommended by the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP), can significantly mitigate unauthorized access and potential security threats to your web service.

reference.name: Authentication Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Validate and sanitize serialized data
countermeasure.desc:
Validating and sanitizing serialized data is essential for maintaining the integrity and security of data within your server-side web service, including REST APIs and gRPC services. These measures are crucial to prevent injection attacks, data tampering, and other vulnerabilities associated with serialization and deserialization processes. Follow these actionable steps to secure your data serialization practices:

Guidelines for Secure Serialization and Deserialization:
  • Conduct rigorous input validation on all serialized data. Ensure that it matches the expected structure, format, and content. Reject any data that fails to meet these predefined standards.
  • Implement schema validation for serialized data. Utilize tools that can check incoming data against a defined schema to confirm its validity and structure.
  • Create a whitelist of permissible values for each field within your serialized data. Disallow any data containing values not included in this list, mitigating the risk of harmful content injections.
  • Impose restrictions on the size and length of serialized data. This limits potential attack vectors by reducing the amount of data an attacker can manipulate.
  • Apply sanitization techniques to serialized data. Remove or alter characters or sequences that could be exploited for malicious purposes.
  • Select secure and regularly updated libraries for data serialization and deserialization. Libraries like Jackson for Java offer built-in security features and are actively maintained to address new vulnerabilities.
  • Incorporate digital signatures with serialized data. This step verifies the authenticity and integrity of the data, ensuring it has not been altered in transit.
  • Establish a robust logging and monitoring system. Keep detailed records of deserialization events and anomalies to detect and respond to potential security incidents swiftly.

By adhering to these steps and integrating security best practices into your development process, you can significantly enhance the safety of your web service. Continuously update your knowledge and tools based on the latest security research and recommendations from authoritative sources, such as OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project), to protect against evolving threats.

reference.name: Deserialization Cheat Sheet

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers abuse the service, e.g., lack of rate limiting
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

When a server-side web service, such as a REST API or a gRPC service, lacks adequate rate limiting, it becomes vulnerable to various forms of abuse. Rate limiting is crucial for controlling the frequency of client requests to prevent overuse and ensure fair resource allocation among users. Without proper rate-limiting controls, attackers can inundate the service with a high volume of requests, potentially leading to denial of service, resource exhaustion, and performance degradation. This vulnerability can also be exploited to facilitate other attack types, such as brute force attacks aimed at guessing user credentials.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The primary threat agents in this scenario are malicious actors or bots designed to exploit weaknesses in web services. Attack vectors include automated scripts or botnets that send a large number of requests in a short period, overwhelming the service. These actors may seek to disrupt the service availability, gain unauthorized access, or exploit the service for other malicious purposes. The lack of rate limiting makes it easier for such actors to carry out their attacks without being detected or throttled by the system.

Impacts

The impacts of failing to implement adequate rate limiting can be severe. It can lead to service degradation, where legitimate users experience slow response times or are unable to access the service altogether. In extreme cases, it can result in a complete denial of service, making the web service unavailable. Furthermore, it can compromise the security of the service by facilitating brute force and other exploitation techniques, potentially leading to unauthorized access and data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker deploys a botnet to send thousands of login requests per minute to a web service that lacks proper rate limiting. The service becomes overwhelmed with the volume of requests, leading to resource exhaustion and significant performance degradation. Legitimate users are unable to access the service, and the attacker may eventually bypass authentication controls through brute force attacks, gaining unauthorized access to sensitive information.

reference.name: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption
OWASP API Security Top 10 - Lack of Resources & Rate Limiting

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1110 - Brute Force||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service||ATT&CK Enterprise - TA0040 - Impact

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers bypass authentication and gain unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers exploiting weaknesses in the authentication mechanisms of a server-side web service, such as a REST API or a gRPC service, pose a significant security threat. Authentication bypass occurs when attackers find ways to circumvent authentication processes, allowing them to impersonate legitimate users or access the service without authorization. This threat can arise from various vulnerabilities, including inadequate access controls, the use of weak or default credentials, insecure session management, and other software flaws that may be exploited through injection attacks or other techniques.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The threat agents in this scenario include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, or automated bots that specifically target authentication mechanisms to gain unauthorized access. These agents might use various attack vectors, such as phishing to steal credentials, exploiting known vulnerabilities in authentication mechanisms, session hijacking, or even using previously leaked credentials obtained from other breaches (credential stuffing).

Impacts

An authentication bypass can lead to severe impacts, including unauthorized access to sensitive data, data manipulation or theft, and potentially gaining elevated privileges within the system. Such incidents can result in financial loss, reputational damage, and legal consequences for the affected organization. Moreover, they compromise the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the service, affecting both the service provider and its users.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker discovers a vulnerability in the session management of a web service, allowing them to hijack an active session of a legitimate user. By exploiting this weakness, the attacker gains unauthorized access to the user's account without needing to bypass the login credentials. In another scenario, an attacker uses a SQL injection flaw in the login form to bypass authentication checks, granting them access to restricted areas of the web service that contain sensitive user data.

reference.name: Broken Access Control: Attack Examples and 4 Defensive Measures
OWASP Top 10:2021 - Identification and Authentication Failures

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1556 - Modify Authentication Process||ATT&CK Enterprise - TA0001 - Initial Access||ATT&CK Enterprise - TA0005 - Defense Evasion||ATT&CK Enterprise - TA0006 - Credential Access||ATT&CK Enterprise - TA0008 - Lateral Movement

threat.name: Attackers craft and inject malicious content, e.g., SQLi
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Injection attacks occur when an attacker crafts and injects malicious content into a server-side web service, such as a REST API or a gRPC service, targeting its data interpreters. SQL Injection (SQLi) is a prevalent form of this threat, but the risk also extends to Command Injection, XML Injection, LDAP Injection, Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), and malicious file executions. These attacks exploit vulnerabilities in the application's input validation mechanisms, allowing the attacker to execute arbitrary commands, manipulate queries, or access unauthorized data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The primary threat agents include cybercriminals, hacking groups, and malicious insiders with knowledge of software vulnerabilities. Attack vectors involve the submission of crafted input data into web forms, URLs, or even in the headers of HTTP requests, aiming to manipulate the backend data processing systems. By exploiting vulnerabilities in how user input is processed and validated, attackers can execute unauthorized commands or queries within the application's underlying databases or operating systems.

Impacts

The impacts of injection attacks can be devastating, leading to data breaches, loss of data integrity, unauthorized access to sensitive information, and complete system compromise. These attacks can result in regulatory penalties, financial losses, and severe damage to an organization's reputation. Moreover, they can undermine user trust in the affected web service, with long-term consequences for user retention and business viability.

Example Attack Scenarios

In an SQL Injection attack, an attacker manipulates input fields or URL parameters to include malicious SQL code, which is then executed by the database server, leading to unauthorized data access. For example, by entering a specially crafted SQL query into a search box, the attacker could dump the database contents, including user credentials. In a Cross-Site Scripting attack, an attacker injects malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users, stealing cookies or session tokens, thereby hijacking user sessions.

reference.name: Top 5 most dangerous injection attacks

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers access information, including secrets, through misconfiguration, errors, or logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improper configurations, coding errors, and insecure logging practices in a server-side web service can lead to the unintentional exposure of sensitive information, including secrets like passwords, API keys, and both system and user data. Such vulnerabilities occur when the web service is not correctly secured, potentially due to oversight, lack of awareness, or misinterpretation of configuration settings. These vulnerabilities can allow attackers to access confidential information that should otherwise be protected, compromising the security and integrity of the web service and its users.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents in these scenarios can range from opportunistic hackers to sophisticated cybercriminals actively scanning for exposed information due to misconfigurations or errors. Attack vectors include exploiting publicly accessible directories, unprotected files, verbose error messages, and logs that contain sensitive information. Attackers may also use automated tools to scan for common misconfigurations or coding errors that lead to information exposure.

Impacts

The exposure of sensitive information through misconfiguration, coding errors, or insecure logging can have severe consequences, including data breaches, identity theft, and unauthorized access to protected resources. It can also lead to loss of customer trust, reputational damage, and potential legal and regulatory implications for the organization. The compromised information can further be used in more sophisticated attacks, amplifying the overall risk to the organization and its stakeholders.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker discovers that a web service's error messages are verbose and include detailed stack traces, revealing database connection strings and API keys. Utilizing this information, the attacker gains unauthorized access to the database and third-party services. In another scenario, an attacker finds a misconfigured server that logs all HTTP requests, including URLs containing unencrypted passwords and tokens. By accessing these logs, the attacker harvests credentials and tokens to impersonate legitimate users or escalate privileges.

reference.name: Information disclosure vulnerabilities and attacks in web applications
Web Service Security Cheat Sheet
